comments.author: MarkleZephire

comments.text:
+MarcoMars I think I know why you think that.

Let's say there was a man with incredible debilitating pain across his 
entire body. A doctor suggests a solution that would remove the pain, but 
also all of his senses (like touch, taste, smell, vision and hearing).
There is a scale by which one can judge whether this "solution" is the 
better choice to make. It measures "quality of life".

When you consider the two possible states of being, in one your experience 
of life is neutral, softened or non-existent, and in the other it is very 
negative. It would seem obvious which choice should be made: Remove the 
pain & senses.

There is another scale that can be used here. It measures "value of 
living". This scale isn't based on your experience of life, but what you're 
capable of doing with it by will. If the pain was continuous or 
debilitating to the extent that the man cannot move/communicate, both 
options would have the same value on this scale, but in any other case the 
better choice would clearly be: Keep the pain & senses.

People tend to use both of these scales in the judgments they make about 
themselves, with a heavy emphasis on "value of living", but when it comes 
to making judgement about others, the primary scale used is "quality of 
life".

So did MD make the right decision to allow for this change in his brain? I 
think you'd need both scales to answer that question, but that's not 
possible. With our limited knowledge of MD's life, we may not know what the 
values might have been.
comments.author: Nawid N.

comments.text:

comments.author: pokee9

comments.text:
+MarcoMars I think there's a distinction between 'human experimentation' 
and studying somebody who had a legitimate medical procedure done and who 
gives consent.

I define 'human experimentation' as the type of stuff the Nazi's and 
Japanese did during WWII. In those cases;
A. Nobody gave consent
B. The experimentation was known to be harmful (often deadly)
C. The procedures were needlessly cruel and not intended in anyway to cure 
anything. 

For example, the Japanese systematically submerged people in ice baths and 
timed how long it took them to die of hypothermia. They also performed live 
vivisections and had people raped purposefully to observe the affects of 
STDs. (Seriously the list of things done at Unit 731 reads like a horror 
novel).

Having said all that, some of the data the Japanese and Nazi's gathered is 
still of medical relevance today, mainly because it couldn't be gathered 
any other way. That's not a statement of support, just an unsettling fact. 

Anyway, I don't object to what was done to HM. Risky medical procedures 
always have a chance of going seriously wrong. As long as they exhausted 
other options and he was made fully aware of the danger, the ultimate 
decision was his to make. 

Gathering data after the experiment was done was also vital for other 
people in future that might be in HM's situation, or have other 
neurological conditions.
comments.author: Merry Machiavelli

top_comment.text:
When Henry Molaison (now widely known as H.M.) cracked his skull in an 
accident, he began blacking out and having seizures. In an attempt to cure 
him, daredevil surgeon Dr. William Skoville removed H.M.'s hippocampus. 
Luckily, the seizures did go away — but so did his long-term memory! Sam 
Kean walks us through this astonishing medical case, detailing everything 
H.M. taught us about the brain and memory.﻿
top_comment.author: TED-Ed

comments.text:
Come on joseph, i was obviously exaggerating by a bunch.

What do you mean at the end? Age does not matter, thats one huuugggeee 
misconception. What i meant by my comment though, is that we dont learn 
things AS interesting and reveloutinary as this. We learn basic repetative 
things that are mainly boring. Only once in awhile do we learn something 
interesting, like a elegant story in english, or a mighty sparta vs athen 
war in history, or hands on expirence with learning how to make different 
pathways with circuits in science, or actually a useful lesson in math. But 
those are only a couple of lessons out the year. Mainly, it is teach to the 
test.

We learn a quick lesson, notes, homework, pre test, test, repeat with new 
lesson. How long do we do that? For TWELVE YEAAARRSSS.

Most of us dont realise that this """education""" system is not.... 
Education. Its called schooling because it is schooling. What is public 
schooling? I think we forget that, US adopted this technique from prussia, 
which is now germany. They created this schooling system to have better 
citizens at then end, to assert conformity. They wanted the soldiers to 
listen and obey all orders; because in the war zones the soldier's would 
kind of fight for themselves, which is a natraul survival program we have, 
especially when adrenaline is kicking.

They created the schooling system, with the. Chopped up schedual, and the 
bells, and the authority, and all these damn rules. Its not really for 
teaching in a honest way, its more of creating the same standerd citizen 
that can do the job, but can't think for himself or question anything.

You know, every year is a hard year in school. Im glad... SOOOO FUCKING 
GLAD, that i only have 2 years left till im 'free' of the prison.... But 
thats just direct prison, once you are released into the "real world" its 
just another massive prison on a bigger scale. But we have the illusion 
that we are free buuuutttt, not really.
I dont wanna make this to long but last point.

I JUST turned 16, and if i said this to most students, or teachers, or even 
adults; i would be called crazy. Im so thankful and humble for the 
oppratunity to 'awaken' has come my way. The interent is such a great place 
and you learn so much. I dont think i would know reality if i did not have 
internet. Tell me, if germans during the nazi created jewish concentration 
camps, had internet like today; would they support what was happening? You 
think they honestly KNEW what was happening? Internet holds so much 
information from others; im honestly humble to live in this generation.

Let me close this out, wayyy too long.

Im sure i dont know everything yet, but im sure as hell awake. In the 
classroom, you cant even fucking talk about something unless its what the 
teacher WANTS you to talk about. How crazy is that? I need a bathroom 
pass..... To excuse my bodily functions? Are you kidding me? You should be 
able to just tell your teacher that you need to use the bathroom, then sign 
out. And thats just being generous, you should be able to just say bye and 
go. I know if everyone did that it would be chaos, but who cares.

I could ramble all day but i think you get the point... Not really a rant 
on you, just felt like typing and typing and typing, haha.

I know there are good teachers, because i also had some good teachers that 
actually want you to learn and are caring.... But within the system, you 
are still the authority figure, and since when in history do you have to 
listen to an authority figure unless its your parents? Question. Why do we 
obey anyways? Because what? Maybe because public school has taught us to 
obey since we were 3-4 untill 18.

OKAY OKAY im done......)::$:)/!:&:$:&:$ hejshdksdshs jeez so hard to 
stop.... Have a good day bye..

comments.text:
+TrindyForce The difference between those two experiences is negligible. 
You're not going to walk past a mirror thinking you're 20 when you're 80 to 
react " oh, what do you know, I'm an old man!" and carry on about your day 
obliviously (within the short-term memory period, of course haha). It's 
going to be a prolonged, traumatic experience whether it comes as part of 
shaving or not. The difference is negligible.

So again, I see no reason for the needless mention of shaving. Unless of 
course you misunderstood the part of the video that explained procedural 
memory (?).

captions.text: On September 1st, 1953,

William Scoville used a hand crank
and a cheap drill saw

to bore into a young man's skull,
cutting away vital pieces of his brain
and sucking them out through a metal tube.

But this wasn't a scene from a horror film
or a gruesome police report.

Dr. Scoville was one of the most 
renowned neurosurgeons of his time,

and the young man was Henry Molaison,
the famous patient known as "H.M.",

whose case provided amazing insights
into how our brains work.

As a boy, Henry had cracked 
his skull in an accident

and soon began having seizures, blacking out
and losing control of bodily functions.

After enduring years of frequent episodes,
and even dropping out of high school,

the desperate young man 
had turned to Dr. Scoville,
a daredevil known for risky surgeries.

Partial lobotomies had been used
for decades to treat mental patients

based on the notion that
mental functions were strictly localized
to corresponding brain areas.

Having successfully used them
to reduce seizures in psychotics,

Scoville decided to remove 
H.M.'s hippocampus,

a part of the limbic system
that was associated with emotion
but whose function was unknown.

At first glance, 
the operation had succeeded.

H.M.'s seizures virtually disappeared,
with no change in personality,
and his IQ even improved.

But there was one problem: 
His memory was shot.

Besides losing most of his memories
from the previous decade,

H.M. was unable to form new ones,
forgetting what day it was,

repeating comments,
and even eating multiple meals in a row.

When Scoville informed another expert,
Wilder Penfield, of the results,

he sent a Ph.D student named Brenda Milner
to study H.M. at his parents' home,

where he now spent his days
doing odd chores,

and watching classic movies
for the first time, over and over.

What she discovered through
a series of tests and interviews

didn't just contribute greatly
to the study of memory.
It redefined what memory even meant.

One of Milner's findings shed light
on the obvious fact

that although H.M. couldn't form new memories,
he still retained information

long enough from moment to moment
to finish a sentence or find the bathroom.
When Milner gave him a random number,

he managed to remember it 
for fifteen minutes
by repeating it to himself constantly.

But only five minutes later,
he forgot the test had even taken place.

Neuroscientists had though of memory
as monolithic,

all of it essentially the same
and stored throughout the brain.

Milner's results were not only the first
clue for the now familiar distinction
between short-term and long-term memory,

but show that each uses 
different brain regions.

We now know that memory formation
involves several steps.

After immediate sensory data is temporarily
transcribed by neurons in the cortex,
it travels to the hippocampus,

where special proteins work to strengthen 
the cortical synaptic connections.
If the experience was strong enough,

or we recall it periodically
in the first few days,

the hippocampus then transfers the memory
back to the cortex for permanent storage.

H.M.'s mind could form
the initial impressions,

but without a hippocampus
to perform this memory consolidation,

they eroded, 
like messages scrawled in sand.

But this was not the 
only memory distinction Milner found.

In a now famous experiment,
she asked H.M. to trace a third star

in the narrow space between 
the outlines of two concentric ones

while he could only see
his paper and pencil through a mirror.

Like anyone else performing such 
an awkward task for the first time,
he did horribly.

But surprisingly, he improved over 
repeated trials,

even though he had no memory
of previous attempts.

His unconscious motor centers remembered
what the conscious mind had forgotten.

What Milner had discovered was that the
declarative memory of names, dates and facts

is different from the procedural memory
of riding a bicycle or signing your name.
And we now know that procedural memory

relies more on the basal ganglia 
and cerebellum,
structures that were intact in H.M.'s brain.

This distinction between "knowing that"
and "knowing how"
has underpinned all memory research since.

H.M. died at the age of 82 after
a mostly peaceful life in a nursing home.

Over the years, he had been examined
by more than 100 neuroscientists,

making his the most 
studied mind in history.

Upon his death, his brain was
preserved and scanned

before being cut into over 2000
individual slices

and photographed to form a digital map
down to the level of individual neurons,

all in a live broadcast
watched by 400,000 people.

Though H.M. spent most of his life
forgetting things,

he and his contributions
to our understanding of memory

will be remembered for 
generations to come.

title: What happens when you remove the hippocampus? - Sam Kean
